mdRecord.dcterms:title: Letter, Eleanor Parke Custis Lewis to Elizabeth Bordley Gibson, No. 78 Walnut Street Philadelphia, 1832 March 19
mdRecord.dcterms:creator: Lewis, Eleanor Parke Custis, 1779-1852
mdRecord.dcterms:description: Mrs. [Thomas] Turner's requirements for a governess -- she has large family -- roads, bad weather and Mr. Lewis's illness have confined them at [Woodlawn] all winter -- unable as yet to see Mrs. G.'s niece, Miss B[ordley] -- gratified with account of Centennial celebration [of George Washington's birth] in Philadelphia -- "Philadelphia has never been backward in showing honor to his memory, altho they have not built a monument yet -- I am ashamed of Virginia, she is to pompous, too parading, too full of words rather than deeds -- she demands that the "remains" should not be removed from the State, and denies anything like a shelter or security for them -- They have tried to induce insurrection by their stupid inflamatory speech only made for effect to the north and [East ?]and deny anything to advance colonization and the real interests of those dark torments of our lives" -- "I was not one of the Petitioners, my dear Elizabeth, & do not approve of Acts which sound loudly, but only increase the evils which menace us -- to do good, we must proceed cautiously and noiselessly - emancipation must be gradual - all this uproar creates discontent, and induces insurrection and murder[.] These ideals, T.J. Randolph, and Faulkner, and some others actually invite murder and outrage by telling these ignorant people that we fear them and are at their mercy - The "Liberator" has done less harm, than the speeches of our delegates" -- "The coach you mention was Govr. Penn's, and presented by the state to Grandmama - It was left in Phia and I do not recollect what became of it" -- Parke has two children, daughter born Feb. 7 [Eleanor Angela Isabella] both alike, and like EPL and their father [Edward Butler]. Name on original manuscript appears as "E. P. L.". Autograph letter initial signed, 4 pages, docketed "March 1831, Recd. March 21-1832", black seal with swan guarding nest & motto "Amour maternel," postmarked Alexa Ca. Mar. 20.
